properties.Summary:
Description: Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing ping pong ball sized hail and wind gusts in excess of 100 km/h. At 4:10 PM CDT Doppler RADAR indicated that this severe thunderstorm was located near Tolstoi and was moving toward the east at 20 km/h. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles.

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A heat event will continue this week. Inland from the Great Lakes, daytime high temperatures near 29 degrees Celsius will accompany humidex values in the low to mid thirties through the next several days. Overnight low temperatures in the mid to upper teens are expected during this period. Please refer to your public forecast for further details on expected temperatures. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index approaching the high risk category. Never leave people or pets inside a parked vehicle. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-06T13:16:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-05T21:17:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2207006126.2020

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms this afternoon and this evening over much of southern Manitoba. A warm and humid airmass is in place over the region and a cold front is approaching from the west. As the cold front lifts the warm humid airmass, thunderstorms will develop. Some of these thunderstorms will have the potential to become severe with hail to the size of golf balls and damaging winds in excess of 90 km/h the most likely threats. In addition, storms will be very moisture-laden so excessive rainfall is possible. ### Rapidly rising rivers and creeks can sweep away bridges, culverts, buildings, and people. Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-06T07:09:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-05T21:20:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2741562589.2020

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 4:46 p.m. CDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a line of severe thunderstorms capable of producing very strong wind gusts, up to nickel size hail and heavy rain. This line of thunderstorms is currently from Wintering Lake southeast to near Molson Lake and is tracking to the northeast at 20 km/h. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Heavy downpours are likely to cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Fast-moving water across a road can sweep a vehicle away. Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
Expires: 2020-07-06T00:26:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-05T21:47:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1758206316.2020

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of dangerous thunderstorms that may be capable of producing damaging wind gusts and large hail. Hazards: - Damaging wind gusts of 90 to 100 km/h - Quarter to Toonie size hail Locations: Portions of Northwestern Ontario including Kenora, Fort Frances, Dryden and Red Lake. Timing: Scattered thunderstorms this afternoon becoming more widespread this evening. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Very strong wind gusts can damage buildings, down trees and blow large vehicles off the road. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm. properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Humidex values reaching 34 are expected for the next 2 days. A hot and humid airmass persists over portions of northern Manitoba today. Cooler temperatures will enter the area tonight as a weak cold front moves in. Extreme heat warnings will likely be ended by morning. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. For more information on heat and your health: - Visit Manitoba Health at: http://www.manitoba.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/heat.html. - Call Health Links Info Sant at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-06T06:59:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-05T20:38:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2355181091.2020

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 4:11 p.m. CDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing very strong wind gusts and up to nickel size hail. This cluster of severe thunderstorms is located from 30 kilometres east of Caliper Lake Provincial Park to 30 kilometres southeast of Caliper Lake Provincial Park to 15 kilometres northwest of Fort Frances, moving east at 65 km/h. Hazards: 100 km/h wind gusts and nickel size hail. Source: RADAR indicated. Locations impacted include: Loonhaunt Lake and Kaiashkons Lake. ### Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles.
Expires: 2020-07-05T23:10:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-05T21:12:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3516451752.2020
Area: Dryden - Vermilion Bay, Fort Frances - Emo - Rainy River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a line of severe thunderstorms capable of producing quarter-sized hail and wind gusts in excess of 100 km/h. At 4:10 PM CDT Doppler RADAR indicated that this line of severe thunderstorms stretched from Oakbank to Oak Bluff to Sanford and was moving toward the east at 20 km/h. Southern Winnipeg will be particularly affected by large hail over the next half hour. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes.
Expires: 2020-07-06T00:04:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-05T21:12:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0740698042.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of dangerous thunderstorms that may be capable of producing damaging wind gusts and large hail. Hazards: - Damaging wind gusts of 90 to 100 km/h - Quarter to Toonie size hail Locations: Portions of Northwestern Ontario including Kenora, Fort Frances, Dryden and Red Lake. Timing: Scattered thunderstorms this afternoon becoming more widespread this evening. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Very strong wind gusts can damage buildings, down trees and blow large vehicles off the road. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm. For more information: http://www.emergencymanagementontario.ca/english/beprepared/beprepared.html.
Expires: 2020-07-06T08:31:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-05T20:52:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3815581804.2020
Area: Sandy Lake - Weagamow Lake - Deer Lake, Pikangikum - Poplar Hill - MacDowell
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 4:11 p.m. CDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a line of severe thunderstorms capable of producing very strong wind gusts, up to nickel size hail and heavy rain. This line of thunderstorms is currently from Wintering Lake southeast to near Molson Lake and is tracking to the northeast at 20 km/h. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Heavy downpours are likely to cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Fast-moving water across a road can sweep a vehicle away. Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
Expires: 2020-07-05T23:26:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-05T21:12:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1217259377.2020

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 4:36 p.m. CDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking an area of severe thunderstorms capable of producing very strong wind gusts and up to nickel size hail. This area of thunderstorms is located along the Ontario - Manitoba border. These thunderstorms are moving east at 40 km/h. Locations impacted include: Kenora, Ingolf, Whitedog, Woodland Caribou Provincial Park and Keewatin. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Locally heavy rain is also possible. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.

properties.Title: Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Squalls with wind gusts up to 45 knots, frequent lightning and poor to very poor visibility in thunderstorms heavy at times are expected or occurring in the area. Thunderstorms near the Ontario - Manitoba border are moving east at 20 knots and are expected to move over Lake of the Woods. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.
